p: Based on the global-average time differentials of energies ( Supplementary Fig. 9) and the conversion rates ( Fig. 2), the time series of generation and dissipation rates are generated (see Methods). Figure 3 displays the global-average generation and dissipation rates, which suggests that all generation/dissipation rates are increasing with time. Table 1 further suggests that all positive trends have confidence levels >90% except for the positive trends of G( P E) (confidence level∼81.3%) and D( K M) (confidence level∼87.2%) from ERA-Interim. The positive trends in the generation and dissipation rates are mainly due to the increasing conversion rates, because the time differentials of energies ( Supplementary Fig. 9) are at least one order of magnitude smaller than the conversion rates ( Fig. 2), so the time differentials of energies do not play significant roles in determining the generation and dissipation rates (see Methods).
